name: What Do They Have in Common? Quiz / Test | Common Bond 10 Questions | 10 Questions

questions.text: Korat, Australian Mist, Chartreux, Nebelung are all...
questions.explanation:
Breeds of cat.

	Many cat breeds are named after their coloration.

questions.text: Cocobolo, Buckeye, Alder and Hornbeam are all...
questions.explanation:
Types of wood.

	Cocobolo is a tropical wood, all the others are temperate species.

questions.text: Stotting, pronking and cantering are all...
options: Processes in the creation of textiles
questions.explanation:
Gaits of a gazelle.

	'Stotting' and 'pronking' are when the gazelle jumps straight up in the air when fleeing a predator. A canter is a gait between a trot and a gallop.

questions.text: Bristol, Manila, Bond and Vellum are all...
questions.explanation:
Types of paper.

	Bristol is an art paper; the others are more widely known.

questions.text: Orthoclase, apatite and spinel are all...
questions.explanation:
Minerals.

	Minerals are composed of just one compound, while rocks contain different minerals.

questions.text: Bar, slug, foot-poundal and bolt are all...
questions.explanation:
Units of measure.

	A bar is a unit of pressure. A slug is a unit of mass. A foot-poundal is a unit of energy. A bolt is a measurement of cloth.

questions.text: Choroid, sclera, macula and fovea are all...
questions.explanation:
Parts of the eye.

	The eye is one of the most complex organs.

questions.text: Prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase are all...
questions.explanation:
Steps of cellular division.

	Sometimes biology class comes in handy!

questions.text: Antimony, Osmium, Polonium and Astatine are all...
questions.explanation:
Elements.

	Elements are made up of just one kind of atom.

questions.text: Gala, Winesap, Pippin and Fuji are all...
questions.explanation:
Types of apples.

	There are dozens of apple varieties in commerce today.
